text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
ADI IGNATIUS: Hi, everybody.

This is Adi Ignatus, editor
in chief of Harvard Business

Review, and welcome to another
episode of HBR Quarantined.

I'm joined by my
co-host, Joshua Macht,

who heads product and innovation
at Harvard Business Publishing.

This show was created
several weeks ago

to connect with all of you who
are still in lockdown, to try

to give you insight on what's
happening in the world of work

and in business, and
with the economy.

Our special guest today
is Samantha Power,

author of a few books, including
the Pulitzer Prize winning

A Problem from Hell, America
and the Age of Genocide.

She was the US ambassador
to the United Nations

from 2013 to 2017, so we
will bring her in a second.

But before then,
Josh, I just want

to talk a little bit about
where we are right now.

So we're just past Memorial
Day weekend in the US.

We saw the pictures of
people hitting the beaches.

This strikes me as
a period of risk.

The New York metro area,
where a third of the cases

and a third of the
deaths occurred

seems to have succeeded
in flattening the curve.

The rest of the country is
continuing to see cases rise.
That's true globally, as well.
But we're going back to work.

So this is really a reminder to
myself as much as anybody else.
This is a time not to relax.

We know the workplaces that
are the most dangerous, those

with poor ventilation,
meatpacking plants, nursing
homes, prisons.

We know where the risk is,
but the risk is everywhere.

And we're going to start
going back to work,

but we're going to
be facing the risk.

And it's important to
stay vigilant to avoid
a deadly second wave.

That's a pretty
serious way to start.

But Josh, let me
kick it over to you.
What are you thinking right now?

JOSHUA MACHT: No,
I mean, I agree.

And I think we all saw the
pictures of Memorial Day,

and people on
beaches and whatnot.

And it does give you pause
because we all have--
there is this fatigue for sure.

But at the same
time, you're going

to keep reminding yourself
that we've got to be vigilant.

This is a long,
long way from over.

I'll tell you the one thing
though that for me, Adi,

and I'm curious if this
is the same for you.

For me, it's like a long
weekend when you come back.

It's nice out, and
you don't go to work.
It's just a strange feeling.

I mean, in some
ways this morning,

I felt more disconnected
than I have in the past.

Normally after a long
weekend, people sort of slowly

trickle in, and you'd
have that conversation

about where people
had been, and just

normal workplace things that
it's sort of a glaring absence
right now.

I don't know if you
feel the same way.

ADI IGNATIUS: Definitely
feel the same way.

We've talked about this before,
that it's the transitions.

The commutes or the clear breaks
between weekend and week day

that are gone now,
and that make our life

seem a little bit groundhog
day, a little bit repetitive.

They're just absolutely missing
that kind of casual interaction
in the office is a tough thing.

Let me remind our
viewers if you want

to pose a question
to Samantha Power,

put your comments
in the comment box,

put a question rather,
in the comment box.

Before we bring
her on, we always

like to show a TikTok that
captures the zeitgeist.

So engineer Dave,
if you could roll

a TikTok that sums up what it's
like on week 11 of lockdown.

SUBJECT 1: I know,
and I can't tell

the difference between
a weekend and a weekday.

And I barely remember what
real pants feel like anymore.
Right?
It's crazy.
It's wild.
Anyway, did you get my email?

ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah, so
we've all been that guy.

We've all seen that
guy, and that's

sort of what life has been
like on this loop for 11
[INAUDIBLE].
One thing quickly.

If you like the show,
it's free obviously.

But if you like what we
do, feel free to subscribe.

Go to hbr.org, and you can
subscribe to all aspects
of Harvard Business Review.

If you're a sponsor,
and you're looking

for a really great opportunity
to get your message across,

well, you'd be hard pressed
to do better than this, Josh.
JOSHUA MACHT: Hell yeah.
This is your spot.
This is your chance.
ADI IGNATIUS: It's true.

All right, so let's
bring in Samantha Power.

As I said, she is the
author of the Pulitzer Prize

winning book, A Problem
from Hell, America
and the Age of Genocide.

And she has a new memoir called
The Education of an Idealist.

She was the US ambassador
to the United Nations

from 2013 to 2017, and
was involved importantly

in the global coalition that
responded to the Ebola epidemic
in West Africa six years ago.

So Samantha, welcome, and
thank you for being here.

SAMANTHA POWER:
Great to be here.

ADI IGNATIUS: So why
don't we jump in?

Talk a little bit about how
are you handling the work life

balance that everybody watching
this is coping with as well.

SAMANTHA POWER: Like many, in a
time of political polarization,

my own emotions
are very polarized.
I feel immensely lucky.

We had a very serious
scare in my family.

It's somebody very close to
me getting COVID, and having
a brutal few weeks.

But he's made it
out, and is very

much on the road to recovery we
hope, although all the science.

We've never had this
experience in our lives

of [INAUDIBLE]
science, hypotheses,

experimentation playing
out before us, those
of us who were not scientists.

We're the recipients of the
inherited wisdom of science,
more often than not.

And so even on questions
of immunity and so forth,
there's a lot of uncertainty.
So there's that.

There's the kind of way
COVID has snuck up close.

But then also as one who even
writes about it in Education

of an Idealist all the lost
time with my young kids,

because I was working a
24/7 national security

job for the first eight
years of my son's life.
Now I have all this time.

I've never cooked anything
more than a hard boiled egg

before COVID struck, and now
I've graduated to aloo gobi,

although I don't know
how good anything is.

But beggars can't be
choosers, and we have
a household of hungry people.

I find homeschooling
excruciating.

It's the hardest
thing I've ever done.

Negotiating with
Russia, fighting

ISIS, [INAUDIBLE]
Ebola epidemic.

Nothing compares to trying to
get your children to treat you

with the authority that you
feel that your parental status
entitles you to.

So like many, I have
a whole new admiration

for what teachers are doing
everyday behind the scenes,

and I say several Hail
Marys a day for summer camp,
desperate for summer camp.

But right now, we have the sort
of worst of all worlds again.

Feeling blessed, but
the worst of all worlds

in terms of kids and
school, because they're

in that stir crazy
time of year anyway.
My kids are 10 and 7.

And so they'd be climbing the
walls under any circumstances.

But if they're
climbing the walls,

and we're doing so even
before it became silly season,

and you're the one tasked
with homeschooling.

You take refuge in
sessions like this one,

where you're not actually
trying to get them to follow
the schedule for the day.

I stopped printing the
schedules out a long time ago.

The standards have
become very, very lax.

But the number of
Hail Marys is going up

as we get closer and
closer to the decision day

for camp, which hasn't come
yet here in Massachusetts.

ADI IGNATIUS: If this
providing you with a break,

we can keep you on the
air for 10, 12 hours.

It used to be a
six hour session.
There are worse things.

JOSHUA MACHT: So camp
was a big deal for me,
and my kids went through it.
They're teenagers now and older.

This year with my co-workers
who have kids of that age
with thinking about camp.

I mean, are you just like
OK, this has got to happen.
Some camp has to happen.

Or are you actually thinking
all right, what would I do.

SAMANTHA POWER: No I mean,
I'm still in the prayer mode.

So I'm desperate
for something that
will allow them to socialize.

I mean, they've
had no play dates
to speak of for three months.

We go on bike rides occasionally
where we're all masked

and they meet their friends,
and then their friends
are six feet ahead.
But I think what camp offers.

There is a maturing that goes
on through socialization.

There is the absence of the
need for parental authority
as well, which is a big factor.

And for me, just wanting them
to be doing something else other

than saying to me, what's
for breakfast, what's

for lunch, what's for dinner,
and then fighting about school
assignments.

But I really think there's just
such value in group dynamics,
group settings.
There is a reason--
other than many of us working--

that we don't
homeschool our kids.

There's something
in the learning

process about cohabitating,
and being with other kids.
I'm just hoping for day camps.

I've given up on
overnight camps.

But also just to
let some energy out.

Parents are trying to get
their kids to go for long walks
with them.

That's one way to
expend energy, but it's

nothing like hitting a tennis
ball, or kicking a soccer ball,
or swimming in a pond.

So again, these are
high class problems

compared to what so many
families are going through.

But this balance and this effort
to hold it together I know

is something that is defining
parental life for so many
right now.

ADI IGNATIUS: We're
going to get you back

to the easy stuff, global
international relations.

COVID-19 has just brought
out, I don't know.

I was going to say
the worst in us.

But it certainly
brought out the worst

in terms of global
cooperation on things

where most people would like
to see more rather than less.

There are times when I think
there's a new world order

setting in which xenophobia
staked in part by fears

of contagion, and
the interaction
will continue to rise.

And that the new world
order is something

a lot less interactive
than what we've seen.

Does that feel inevitable
to you, as well?

SAMANTHA POWER: Nothing
ever seems inevitable to me,

just having seen the zigs
and zags of recent decades,

and even in certain parts of
the world, in recent months.

This is the classic almost
paradigmatic science fiction

case, where the
alien invader comes

and Ronald Reagan even
in a speech of the nature

before the General
Assembly factor in the Cold

War for the UN General
Assembly saying,

sometimes you almost
wish the aliens

would come so as to forge
that kind of cooperation.
This is the moment.

We have so much to
learn from one another.

The standard spread
of the disease

makes such learning
life and death, even.

If we had looked ahead to
what China was going through,

what Italy was going
through, we could

have been better
prepared ourselves
here in the United States.

The need to pool our
resources in order

to aid those in
developing countries

who don't have anywhere near
the infrastructure that we have,

not even clean running
water in the household,

overcrowded conditions that
go well beyond anything, even

in very crowded communities
in this country.

So we are connected to
those countries in the sense

that our supply
chains might extend

into a place like Bangladesh,
or our family ties certainly

extend into India,
Nigeria, Somalia.

There is no wishing away
the last couple 100 years

of civilization's development
and interconnecting.

And yet, we are acting
as if we can go it alone.

And in the case of the
United States government,

really not seeing our future as
linked to the fates of people

living elsewhere, even
though our economy almost

by definition cannot return to
normalcy the degree that it can
ever.

It can't return if the
markets for our products

are themselves shuttered
in the parts of the world,

or if travel is shut off
to places that are, again,

critical parts of the
virtual assembly line
that exists around the world.

So to your question, I
mean, xenophobia will go up.

And it has spiked
in different places.

A lot of it depends
on leadership.

So what you see in
a lot of countries

is that the
predisposition of a leader

prior to the onset
of COVID tells you

a lot about the extent to
which that leader is preaching

regional and global cooperation
and solidarity right now,

or looking to find
scapegoats, usually

for one's own mishandling
of the pandemic.

And so that's where,
again, I don't succumb
to theories of inevitability.
It's about human agency.

I think what gets challenging
in a period like this where

already 52 countries
have postponed

elections, or
canceled elections,

is how does dissent
get expressed.

When somebody is using their
pulpit to blame the other,

to blame the foreigner,
to blame the minority,

to blame whatever
form it may be taking

with everybody else
confined and experimenting
in online organizing.

But how do the kinds of
protests that have taken

hold over the last two
years, many of which

had deleterious
economic effects,

but nonetheless
were an expression

of a lot of discontent with
incumbents around the world.
Where does that go?
Where does that energy go?

And to what degree will
advanced democracies

that manage to get past the
worst of the pandemic start

to use their voices, their
pressure tactics to pay

attention to what someone
in Hungary or Poland

may be doing to take
advantage of a crisis
to extend their powers.

And again, to use that pulpit in
a way that divides rather than
unites citizens.

But there are lots of
examples now of the countries

that have been extremely
successful in managing

both the economic and the
health effects of the pandemic.

They're doing so by
bringing people together,

and by embracing
narratives of solidarity.

And that they [INAUDIBLE]
to contain their problems,

it's nice to see
them getting also

to step up within
international institutions,

and feel as that they have
something to offer on behalf

of those who haven't yet
been walloped in the way
that they soon will.

JOSHUA MACHT: I
mean, in our country,

I feel like we're just
so fragmented right
here in our response.

Thinking about what you did
with the Obama administration

when there was the
Ebola outbreak,

and reading more about how
countries came together
and what we did to lead that.

To help us to understand first
of all, some of the parallels

to that situation, or maybe some
of the ways that it's part--

what we're seeing now
departs from that.

And it just doesn't
feel like we're

taking those lessons
forward, and what's

stopping us from really
coming together in the ways
that you're talking about?

SAMANTHA POWER: Well,
thank you for asking.

I mean, the Ebola case
is, of course, different,

especially if we start
the clock right now

where the COVID has spread
to every country on earth

practically, and where you
have millions of infections.

Ebola started confined in
West Africa, Liberia, Guinea,
and Sierra Leone back in 2014.

The worst Ebola outbreak
that the world had ever seen,

and the projections that we
got in the situation room

were that 1.4
million people will

be infected, even just in the
region within four or five
months.

And so we saw a slide that looks
a lot like the kind of curves

we saw and continue to see in
different countries showing

that spike, and with the CDC
pleading to President Obama

that we take a set of actions in
order to try to bend the curve,

flatten the curve, and then
eventually eliminate the curve.

And President Obama didn't
need to be convinced.

He recognized that the only
way international institutions

work-- and this is
very much true today--

is if there is a catalytic
leading actor, a first mover.

And he recognized just as every
other president has recognized

for the last seven
decades that by and large,

if it isn't the United
States, it isn't anybody.

And so what President
Obama decided to do--

despite the fact that even
Democrats in his own party were
very skeptical of his approach--

was to send 3,000 troops
and health workers

into the eye of the
storm, into West Africa.

Donald Trump was then a reality
TV show host, of course,

but he would actually really
came to the fore politically

in part because of
the tweets that he--

I don't want to repeat the
word tweeted, but admitted

the tweets that he put forth
in the midst of this epidemic.

And they got huge
traction, not only on Fox,

but they actually broke
through into the mainstream

and outside of right
wing media sites.

This began to spook, again,
even Democratic governors
and Democratic politicians.

And there was a fear that
if you go there to help,

you'll end up bringing
it here much more

than would otherwise
be the case.

We already had an
isolated case of somebody
who'd come from Liberia.

So the appeals were
to close the borders.

In that instance, that
was the wrong approach.

The public health experts in our
own government made that clear.

Obviously in the COVID case,
it was the right approach.

It's a cost benefit
in every instance.

But what was the
right approach was

to go into the
heart of the storm

and then use what you're doing
to leverage other countries
to do far more.

So we took leadership
on Liberia.

We went to the British and said,
will you take Sierra Leone.
The British said, we got this.

We're just running point backing
the people of Sierra Leone
we're doing the real work.

The French took
leadership in Guinea.

We went to China
and said, OK, you're

ready to be part
of a so-called P2.

How many Ebola
treatment units are you

going to build in
these three countries?

How many labs are
you going to set up?

This is the number
that we're setting up.

The Malaysians contributed
tens of thousands
of [INAUDIBLE] of rubber gloves.

The Cubans, more
health workers and docs

per capita than any other
country contributing
to the coalition.

So this is how
coalitions are built.

There's a temptation to say
why doesn't the UN just snap
its fingers and make it happen.

Well, the UN is a building
comprised of countries
that are run by governments.

And like any collective
action problem--

and we see this in our
business world often--

in any group setting, it
requires a first mover.

And the problem for the first
couple months of this pandemic

is that the first
mover was China.

China, first of course,
covering up what it was doing,
providing bad information.

Then as a first mover,
it began to first move

outside of
international settings,

so providing
bilateral assistance.

Not leveraging what it was doing
to get other countries to chip
in.

The United States
retreated altogether.

It had already pulled
back significantly.

So we weren't there in
the way that we have been
for every other major crisis.

And now, just in the
last couple of weeks,

China has begun to
shift to try to lead

within international
institutions.

Seeing an opening
to spread its wings

and to cement its role
as the global leader,
as the leader of the world.

I mean, this is what President
Xi's announcement last week

of a $2 billion
vaccine contribution

to try to pull vaccine knowledge
and ultimately distribution
to developing countries.

He actually did that not
as China bilaterally,

as China has usually done, but
did it within the World Health

Organization, where the US
has vacated its premise.

The other thing
we're seeing though--

and I think this is really
instructive in terms

of a happier story about
how things can develop--

is that those countries like
New Zealand, Australia, Korea,

Denmark, Germany,
that have managed

to get a grip on the
pandemic within their borders

have created something
called the first movers club.

And they are now seeking to pool
their energies as democracies

within international
institutions

to create a kind of
block that offers
its expertise, its resources.

But also, we don't
want to live in a world

where the China
model of governance

then gets imported into
international institutions.

And for the first three
years of Trump's leadership,

middle powers have
tended to just

be recessive in those
organizations, kind

of waiting for the United
States to show up again.

And now, the pandemic
has really brought home

that that-- at least in
this administration--
is unlikely to happen.
And time to get busy.

If we don't want to
see the norms that

have defined international
statecraft for the last 75

years altered, and looking more
and more like Chinese norms,

those countries are going to
have to raise their voices

and take leadership
roles they haven't really
taken up to this point.

ADI IGNATIUS: If you just joined
us, this is HBR Quarantined.

Our guest is Ambassador
Samantha Power.

If you have questions
for her, please
put them in the comments.

We'll try to get to
some in a little bit.
Samantha, I want to ask--
I want to take on the question.

You've just written this book,
Education of an Idealist.

When I think of shattered
idealism for myself.

I view myself as
an idealist, and I
find governments let you down.
NGOs let you down.
Almost everything lets you down.

I actually find solace sometimes
in the world of business.

I don't mean to overstate
business as good
as opposed to being neutral.

But there are companies
that within the ecosystem

of a business can try
to do the right thing,

and to try to create an
environment that cares
about whatever issues matter.

Environmental,
social, governance,
sort of other things.
These little microcosms.

So my question for
you is, where does

an American idealist
like yourself
find solace these days.
SAMANTHA POWER: Thank you.

I mean, I think that
some of the trends

that we've seen with
business leaders

well before the pandemic
stepping up and saying,

it's not just about
the bottom line.

I mean, this trend
has been at work,

and it's never
entirely clear what's

motivating a particular leader
in a particular circumstance.

But more and more seeing the
business roundtable and others

step up and take note
of the warming planet

around us, companies
that have been

able to get through this
pandemic without big blows.

Stepping into the void where
charities and others are really
flailing.

I just saw last week Oxfam
pulling out of 18 countries

because they can no longer
pay the bills there.

UN humanitarian work all
around the world shriveling up

as resources get
diverted to deal

with really difficult
domestic circumstances
for developed countries.

And so for the private
sector to do more of that,

I mean, again, it comes
back to individual agency.

In my own career, as I
write about in the book,

I just saw too often
individuals change the world.

And it may be that the slice
of the world that they changed
was small.

Again, the climate
kept warming, even

as we were able in support
of the people in West Africa

to bring the Ebola
epidemic to an end.

But if you set your sights on
changing everything at once,

then that is a recipe
for disillusionment.

And maybe just watching The
Last Dance over and over

and not seeing the world
the world around you.

It can be really
tempting to turn off,

if you think you can solve the
biggest problems of our time

either by yourself
or all at once.

So I fastened when I was
in government on an idea

that actually,
writers who I think

are beloved in the business
world, the Heath brothers.
They wrote a book called Switch.

And they had this
idea, and it really

resonated for me in government,
which was shrink the change.

Find that small
slice of change that
actually is within your scope.

So for example, when
I was in the cabinet

with the president of the
United States as UN ambassador.

At the very time, I was at the
highest levels of government.

We were experiencing
something that

continues to this day, which
is a human rights recession all
around the world.

We're now in the 14th
straight year of human rights
being in decline.

Now, we had an explosive
growth in human rights

and civil society and so forth
after the end of the Cold War.

But those trend lines have gone
in a negative direction in part

because of the xenophobia
and nationalism
you mentioned earlier.

But I'm thinking here I am,
human rights advocate actually

at the highest
levels of government.

What am I doing about the
human rights recession?

And if you ask the
question in that way,

again, you could just
feel immensely small.

And I think people right
now given the crisis,

are feeling very, very
small and disempowered.

[INAUDIBLE] I sat down
with my team and I
read about this new book.

And I said, what can
we do that's just
a tiny piece of this.

And we decided we
were going to set

our sights on just getting 20
female political prisoners out
of jail.

That was so modest
for the US government
to be doing this next to this--

all these years of
freedom in decline.

But we profiled each of
these women on social media.

Some were exposing corruption
in their government,

some were protesting
sexual harassment in China.

And we hung jumbo photos of
these women in the US mission

to the UN in the window
when heads of state

were coming to town in September
for the General Assembly.

We teamed up in
a bipartisan way.

The forgotten
practice of bipartisan

backed diplomacy, where we got
the 20 US female senators who

were in the US senate
at the time, Republican

and Democratic, to
back the campaign.

And 16 of the 20 women were
ultimately freed from jail,

and went back to making
trouble, and holding
their governments accountable.

And I use this example not
because it by any means

changed the world,
but [INAUDIBLE]

to describe the
effect on my team,

and the way that they
went about their business.

The tangible nature
of that, which

was so concrete and yet so
small next to the abstraction
of freedom in decline.

People who in COVID, are
now creating these shopping
angels networks.

I know just shopping
for elderly neighbors

gives you a sense of meaning,
and purpose, and impact.

So you can't change all of
these structural trends that

are defining our plight
at a given moment.

But it is a mistake to think
that you can come up with a--

usually-- a solution
commensurate with the scale
of the challenge.

The question is,
what is your slice.

And I think in
thinking that way,

it breeds an idealism and a
greater sense of empowerment.

JOSHUA MACHT: I know we've
got some other things

that we want to talk
about on the sports front
and everything.
But I want to one kind of big--

sort of big, heavy
question for you.

Because I'm curious what you
think about the whole notion
of national security.

It feels at the
very least like we
broaden the definition of it.

It feels like the
definition is changing
of what that really means.

And it kind of seems like that
has some scary implications,

and I'm wondering what
your thinking on that is.

SAMANTHA POWER: Yeah, I mean,
I think that rhetorically, it
has been altered for some time.

We have talked about
national security

as entailing threats
that cross borders.

We rhetorically-- certainly
since 9/11 at the very least--

have talked about the ways
that borders don't insulate us

from terrorists who
can move their finances

in a different way or
